title: World Wide Haxe 2016
description:
The 6th International Haxe Conference. Held 27-30 May 2015 in Paris, France.
More info on silexlabs.org/2016/

Here is the intro of the World Wide Haxe conference organized by Silex Labs and hosted by Mozilla Paris. Jean-Baptiste Richardet, general secretary of the non-profit organization Silex Labs, presents what is the wwx, how was it made...

videos.title: "Shooting for the Moon: Haxe lands on Lua" by Justin Donaldson
videos.description:
Justin Donaldson's talk at the WWX2016 about the 10th Haxe's target: Lua

Talk description:
Lua is a language that can play many roles: A light-weight memory-safe scripting environment suitable for embedded devices, a speedy jit with a flexible C FFI for high performance web development, or even the language for a state of the art machine learning framework. However, as a scripting language Lua suffers from the same scalability problems that plague large dynamic language codebases.

Haxe's ability to effectively organize and compose projects makes Haxe/Lua projects an ideal approach for developing complex Lua applications. This talk will cover the basics of how the Haxe language maps to Lua internals, and cover some useful topics such as avoiding pitfalls, using helpful workarounds, and getting the most out of your next Haxe/Lua project.

http://wwx.silexlabs.org/2016/talks/justin-donaldson.html

Slides:
http://wwx.silexlabs.org/2016/assets/presentations/justin-donaldson.pdf

The WWX is a 4 day conference about Haxe a high-level multi-platform open source programming language.The WWX2016 is organized by Silex Labs and sponsored by Haxe foundation, Mozilla, Gandi, Docler Holding, Secret Media and Keymetrics.

videos.title: "pistahx: type safe, design first, Haxe web API" by Emmanuel Botro
videos.description:
pistahx is presented by its fouder Emmanuel Botros at the WWX2016.

Description talk:
Pistahx is a modern, design first web api framework. Based on Haxe, it helps coders to write clean and type-safe Business classes. It targets the Nodejs ecosystem, so your api can be deployed and scaled on almost any stack/cloud. We also offer a minimal dockerhub image called pistahx-docker-stack to help you deploy your apps within docker containers. Pistahx uses Redis as an ultra-fast cache store (multiple cache layers are available). Pistahx implements the OpenAPI specification (formerly known as swagger) and auto-generates an interactive documentation. You can also use additional modules to generate Haxe typedefs from your API specification (pistahx-spec), and from your DB schema (pistahx-db, optionnal) among many other stuff.

Slides: http://wwx.silexlabs.org/2016/assets/presentations/emmanuel-botros.pdf

More info:
http://wwx.silexlabs.org/2016/talks/emmanuel-botros.html

More vidéo WWX2016 videos on http://wwx.silexlabs.org/2016/

videos.title: "JTRansc: JAVA and Kotlin everywhere through Haxe" by Carlos Ballestero
videos.description:
In this talk Carlos Ballesteros will explain what is JTransc, how does it works and why he did it. Also he will explain how to integrate with haxe libraries and how to embed plain haxe code. He will show the current workflow and will talk about the future of the project.

-What is JTransc
-How does it works (overview)
-Productivity over writting haxe directly
-Sharing code with java backends
-Why JTransc instead of other alternatives like: GWT, RoboVM, TeaVM, plain kotlin js
-Why target to Haxe
-How to integrate with haxe libraries
-Demos
-Future

Slides:
http://wwx.silexlabs.org/2016/assets/presentations/carlos-ballesteros.pdf

Jtransc's website:
http://blog.jtransc.com/

videos.title: "HaxeUI Version 2 - Multi-platform, multi-framework ui" by Ian Harrigan
videos.description:
In this talk Ian Harrigan will go over some of the limitations and problems surrounding version 1 of HaxeUI and how they are addressed in version 2. As well as introducing some of the newer features incorporated in version 2 like its ability to use any render framework, its enhanced scripting abilities and its ability produce native and hybrid UIs.

videos.title: "hexMachina: urban framework for hardcore developers" by Francis Bourr
videos.description:
Here is the talk of Francis Bourre on HexMachina a powerfull multi-modular MVC framework written in Haxe.

Talk's description:
During the last decade, the web evolved a lot. Applications became rich, complex, smart, interactive... And, like their desktop grand sistas, they had to be more and more maintainable, scalable and flexible.

This talks is about code design, and building solutions with Haxe language to provide the right answers to maintain long life-cycle applications. Sources of inspiration are many. All the concepts and ideas grew up in the street, result of 15 years of experience, exploring many other languages and technologies, and last but not least, fighting in the browser's jungle with games, websites and applications development.

This presentation is targeted to every hardcore developer who wants to share some urban inspiration about code design, and have a first taste with the HexMachina framework.
http://wwx.silexlabs.org/2016/talks/francis-bourre.html

Slides of the talk:
https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1qR0zvW5Rv_g3CK3itDiDQim6Ui9PMQcRy4oExqcvmBo/edit#slide=id.g112d046e3c_0_341

hexMachina website:
http://hexmachina.org/

https://youtu.be/emmglbk8m9Q

videos.title: "Highway to the external world: Generate externs programmatic" by Andy L
videos.description:
It is Andy Li's talk at the WWX2016.

Description talk:
Let’s face it: There are at least 100 times more libraries written in any one of the Haxe target languages than the ones written in Haxe. We don’t and shouldn’t have to reinvent the wheel all the time. And we shouldn’t spend countless hours on writing externs, which could still be incomplete and quickly become outdated.

More info: http://wwx.silexlabs.org/2016/talks/andy-li.html
Slides: http://wwx.silexlabs.org/2016/assets/presentations/andy-li.pdf

videos.title: "HXCPP" - What's new" by Hugh Sanderson
videos.description:
Here is Hugh Sanderson's talk at the WWX2016

Talk description:
Quite a bit has gone on under the hood of the hxcpp backend in 2016. Find out what a low-level rewrite of the garbage collector, a refactor of the ocaml code and improved representations of objects, enum and interfaces means to you. With lots of community support this year, the native integration has been driven forward, and this talk may help you find easy ways to integrate hxcpp into your projects.

More info:
http://wwx.silexlabs.org/2016/talks/hugh-sanderson.html

videos.title: "Haxe-dev: tales from within" by Simon Krajewsk
videos.description:
Here is the talk of Simon Krajewski main maintainer of the Haxe compiler at the WWX2016.

Description talk:
Even after over 10 years, the Haxe Compiler and its related technologies are in constant development. This is made possible by a strong development community which has grown over the years and continues to grow.

This talk explores what happened since WWX 2015, and who made it happen. While there's a natural technical focus given the subject matter, it is also going to highlight some interpersonal aspects of open source development. Expect a mixture of development anecdotes and compiler-related tech-talk.

Slides:
http://wwx.silexlabs.org/2016/assets/presentations/simon-krajewski/

videos.title: "The Secret stack" by Alexandre Hoya
videos.description:
At Secret Media we tackle the hotest issue of today's web: the unacceptable practices of advertisers. Secret Media has taken a very complex challenge: to fix it with only tech, and without anyone noticing it. The technical solution is made of Haxe and sweat, that's the secret stack.

videos.description:
Whether or not you've jumped on the React bandwagon, it has introduced (or at least popularised) some powerful new approaches to building and thinking about user interfaces. In this talk I'll show you how a sprinkling of Haxe can make things even better. Come on, all the cool kids are doing it.

videos.title: "Using Haxe with Unity3D and node.js" by Dan Korostele
videos.description:
This is a talk about one of many Haxe use cases: a language for game logic shared between client and server, both of which are programmed in different languages and environments (Unity/C# and Node.JS). We'll cover how we ended up with Haxe, how it worked out, what issues did we have and how we dealt (or not) with them.

Slides:
http://wwx.silexlabs.org/2016/assets/presentations/dan-korostelev.pdf

videos.title: "Unreal.hx: Using Haxe with the Unreal Engine 4" by Cauê Wanec
videos.description:
In this talk, Cauê presents at the WWX2016 Proletariat's latest library, Unreal.hx, which integrates Haxe into the Unreal Engine in a more feature complete manner than any other language integration, apart from the official C++. He shows how to setup a project, how the project uses macros to achieve this tight integration with the C++ API, and how it uses the cppia VM to leverage faster iteration. He discusses also how the created Unreal.hx toolchain might be used to integrate other C++ libraries with Haxe out-of-the-box.

More info:
http://wwx.silexlabs.org/2016/talks/caue-waneck.html

Slides:
http://wwx.silexlabs.org/2016/assets/presentations/caue-waneck/
